repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Urban Rehabilitation Project
            and Local Government Reform and Engineering Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Rehabilitation Project's
            outcome is rated as unsatisfactory, sustainability as
            unlikely, institutional development impact as negligible,
            Bank performance as highly unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance as highly unsatisfactory. The Local Government
            Reform and Engineering Project's outcome is rated as
            unsatisfactory, sustainability as likely, institutional
            development impact as modest, Bank performance as highly
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance as highly
            unsatisfactory. The results of more than a decade of Bank
            assistance to Mozambique's cities have been
            disappointing. The Bank needs to give more attention to the
            role of cities in the country's economy and the
            government's modest yet politically significant
            decentralization reform. Continuous and rigorous oversight
            by Bank management of Bank/borrower relations is needed to
            detect and correct failings before project outcomes suffer.
            A perfunctory attitude by the Bank toward borrower reports
            of final costs, audits, and implementation completion
            reports can undermine borrower accountability and learning
            too. In order to succeed, projects in war-affected countries
            must take explicit account of the conflict.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Local Government Reform and
            Engineering Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            conducive to effective governance, and public administration
            legislatures, from which stems the decentralization program
            in Mozambique, and, the enactment, and establishment of new
            municipal governments. Nonetheless, the legislative
            framework needs to be completed, to build municipal
            governments' capacity, and thus, expand their
            authority. The key lessons convey the importance of
            obtaining the government's commitment at the policy
            making level, as demonstrated by the success of the project,
            which overcame performance problems, and political
            difficulties. Unfortunately, and regardless of success, the
            design of the project was limited by the choice for an
            Engineering Credit Instrument - intended for large
            investment projects - which failed to provide the required
            flexibility, and, allowed neither learning, nor long-term
            support, that other instruments do provide nowadays. In
            turn, the inadequate assessment, and management of project
            risks, was the consequence of inflexible design, where the
            risks and uncertainties of decentralization, would have
            better evolved, by undertaking a fundamental project
            restructuring. Since difficulties existed due to the
            inclusion of several components, magnified by the
            constrained-capacity environment, essential streamlined,
            management structures should have been considered, in
            addition to management training.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Local Government Reform and
            Engineering Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project supports the Government of
            Mozambique's (GOM) decentralization program by
            assisting with its municipal reform and capacity building
            initiatives. The reforms focus on the legal, institutional
            and fiscal framework of local government in order to create
            a suitable structure for self-sufficient and accountable
            local authorities, and are implemented on a pilot basis in
            five urban areas designated as the project cities.
            Complementary objectives include assisting the GOM to: (a)
            create an appropriate policy framework for investments in
            the urban sector; (b) prepare urban investment plans for
            five project cities, including plans for the efficient
            management, rehabilitation, and financing of essential urban
            infrastructure and services; (c) test specific, replicable
            approaches to solving entrenched urban problems (including
            absorption of rural migrants, environmental degradation, low
            cost transportation); and (d) coordinate the work of donor
            agencies, multilateral and non-governmental organizations
            (NGOs) in the urban/local government sector. The project
            finances technical assistance and studies, and also provides
            for the selective implementation of the findings of these
            studies, including some modest pilot investments in the five
            project cities. The project comprises: (i) legal and
            institutional reform; (ii) fiscal, financial and
            organizational reform; (iii) urban/environmental management;
            and (iv) capacity building, institutional support and
            project management.
